abstract:
**Abstract**  
• A novel Multi-modal Time Series Analysis Model Based on Spiking Neural Network (MTSA-SNN) is proposed  
• The model integrates pulse encoding, joint learning, and wavelet transform for complex time-series analysis  
• Experimental results demonstrate superior performance on three diverse time-series tasks  
• The work provides an effective event-driven approach for non-stationary temporal data  

**Introduction**  
• Traditional Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) face challenges in processing non-stationary time-series data  
• Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) offer advantages in temporal information processing but lack multi-modal fusion capabilities  
• MTSA-SNN addresses key limitations through innovative pulse encoding and joint learning mechanisms  
• The model combines SNNs with wavelet transform for enhanced time-frequency analysis  

**Related Work**  
• Existing approaches include ARIMA models and deep learning methods like Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks  
• Multi-modal time series analysis typically employs Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM)  
• Current SNN applications focus on single-modal tasks like financial forecasting and arrhythmia detection  
• The proposed method advances beyond these limitations through multi-modal pulse fusion  

**Methodology**  
• The Pulse Encoder transforms multi-modal data ($S_{image}$, $S_{series}$) into spike signals ($\hat{S}_1$, $\hat{S}_2$)  
• Joint Learning Module employs Fourier Transform ($FT$) and weight allocation ($P_{mtsa}$) for cross-modal fusion  
• Wavelet transform decomposes signals into LL, LH, HH, HL subbands for multi-scale analysis  
• Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) model governs neuron dynamics with membrane potential $V(t)$  

**Experiment**  
• Evaluated on MIT-BIH (98.75% accuracy), ETT (MSE 0.235), and stock market datasets (MAE 0.961)  
• Outperforms benchmarks including LSTM, XGBoost, and state-of-the-art SNN variants  
• Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of joint learning and wavelet transform components  
• Neuron activation heatmaps demonstrate enhanced temporal representation capability  

**Conclusion**  
• MTSA-SNN establishes a new paradigm for multi-modal time-series analysis using SNNs  
• The pulse-based fusion framework effectively handles non-stationary and event-driven data  
• Wavelet integration significantly improves multi-scale feature extraction  
• Future work will explore applications in real-time streaming data scenarios
